name: Hydrogen Peroxide (3%)
use: Induces vomiting in cases of poisoning, but only under veterinary guidance.
dosage: 1 teaspoon per 10 pounds of body weight, not to exceed 3 tablespoons.
instructions: Use only if instructed by a vet, as inducing vomiting can sometimes cause more harm depending on the substance ingested.

name: Betadine (Povidone-Iodine) Ointment
use: Treats minor cuts, wounds, or skin infections.
instructions: Apply a small amount to the affected area 1-3 times daily. Prevent the dog from licking the area.

name: Antiseptic Wipes
instructions: Gently clean the area around the wound, avoiding the wound itself initially. Use as needed.

name: Avil (Pheniramine Maleate)
use: Addresses allergic reactions, bites, or stings.
dosage: 1 mg per pound of body weight.
instructions: Administer orally, but confirm the exact dosage and use with your veterinarian beforehand.

name: Activated Charcoal Tablets (Carbophos)
use: Absorbs toxins in cases of poisoning.
instructions: Administer as directed by a vet, typically mixed with a small amount of water.

name: Saline Solution (Normal Saline)
use: Rinses out wounds, eyes, or flushes out debris.
instructions: Flush the affected area gently with the solution. Use sterile saline to prevent further contamination.

name: Meloxicam (Metacam)
instructions: Use only medications prescribed by your veterinarian. Follow the prescribed dosage strictly.

name: Electral (Electrolyte Powder)
dosage: As per instructions on the packet.
instructions: Mix the powder with water as per instructions and offer small amounts frequently to the dog. Consult a vet for exact administration advice.

name: Styptic Powder (Kwik Stop)
use: Stops minor bleeding from nails or small cuts.
instructions: Apply directly to the bleeding area. Apply pressure if necessary to stop the bleeding.

name: Otibiotic Ear Drops
instructions: Apply a few drops into the ear canal and gently massage the base of the ear. Wipe away any excess solution.
